abstract.p: Dist Atty Charles J Hynes letter objects to May 18 article characterizing his 1998 gubernatorial bid as 'nuisance' (S)

block.p: Re ''Effort to Oust Assembly Speaker Upsets Democrats' Show of Unity'' (front page, May 18):

If there was ever any question as to the sources of the voting public's cynicism and lack of enthusiasm regarding participatory politics, part of the problem can be traced to comments like those behind the statement that my gubernatorial candidacy was ''widely viewed as no more than a nuisance.''
Re ''Effort to Oust Assembly Speaker Upsets Democrats' Show of Unity'' (front page, May 18):

If there was ever any question as to the sources of the voting public's cynicism and lack of enthusiasm regarding participatory politics, part of the problem can be traced to comments like those behind the statement that my gubernatorial candidacy was ''widely viewed as no more than a nuisance.''
The fact is that I was, together with Peter F. Vallone, the speaker of the New York City Council, the co-nominee of the Democratic Convention in May 1998.

What of the other Democratic candidacies in that election: was James L. Larocca's an annoyance? Betsy McCaughey Ross's bothersome? Who is so privileged to make such designations? Those who wish to control the process for their own benefit and not that of the general public, I assure you.
CHARLES J. HYNES District Attorney, Kings County Brooklyn, May 18, 2000
